en: Come with me.
This one look like delicious.
All bamboos are alike! How am I supposed to do?
fr: Tous les bambous se ressemblent. Comment je fais moi ?

en: Maybe he can help me...
What a strange critter...
You know I can hear you, right?
fr: Tu sais que je t'entends, n'est-ce pas ?

en: What? You can talk!?
Sure, can't you?
Good point.
You're a chameleon right?
fr: Tu es un caméléon, n'est-ce pas ?

en: You're a chameleon right?
fr: Tu es un caméléon, n'est-ce pas ?

en: That's right!
What's a chameleon doing here?
What's a chameleon doing in this part of the world?
fr: Que fait un caméléon dans cette partie du monde ?

en: Oh you know, I just like traveling a lot.
fr: Oh tu sais, j'aime juste voyager.

en: I have never seen one before!
fr: Je n'en avais encore jamais vu !

en: Whoooah! I've never seen one before!
fr: Whoaou ! Je n'en n'avais jamais vu encore !

en: I guess not many of us are around this part of the globe.
fr: Je crois que nous sommes très peu dans cette partie du monde.

en: Nevermind
Nevermind.
Do you enjoy our bamboo forest?
Do you enjoy our bamboo forest? Are you comfortable?
fr: Apprécies-tu la forêt de bambou ? Tu te sens bien ici ?

en: Sure, I like it. Where are all other pandas though?
fr: Bien sûr, je l'adore. Mais où sont les autres pandas ?

en: Aliens
Aliens abducted them!
Hahahaha! Nice one little panda!
Forest destruction
The humans are destroying our forest with their machines...
fr: Les humains ont détruit notre forêt avec leurs machines...

en: Ow, that doesn't sound so nice, are you doing anything about it?
fr: Oh, cela ne semble pas bon ça, fais-tu quelque chose contre cela ?

en: No
No... We can't do anything I guess.
fr: Non... mais je crois que nous ne pouvons rien faire.

en: Oh, I see...
Imploring the Pandas' god
We are making offerings for the Pandas' god so that we can ask him for help. I'm actually gathering some fine bamboos for him! It would be my very first offering to him.
fr: On est en train de réaliser une offrande au Grand Panda, pour implorer son aide. Je suis en train de collecter des bambous pour lui. Cela sera ma première offrande !

en: Well! Today is your lucky day, as I am the Pandas' god! You passed my little test, now bring me the bamboo you found.
fr: Super ! Aujourd'hui, c'est ton jour de chance, puisque je suis le Grand Panda ! Tu as réussi mon petit test, maintenant amène-moi le bambou que tu as trouvé.

en: Nevermind
Nevermind.
Nevermind
Nevermind.
Nevermind
Nevermind.
Hey! Get your hands off me!
fr: Hey ! Enlève tes sales pattes de moi !

en: I took it off without difficulty.
This bamboo it's perfect! Maybe a little too much...
fr: Ce bambou est parfait ! Quoique, peut être un peu trop....

en: All your leaves have the same size.
fr: Toutes tes feuilles ont la même taille.

en: You were hiding little bamboo?
Hey! It's mine!
Sorry, I need this one in particular for my mission...
fr: Pardon mais j'ai besoin de celui-là exactement pour ma mission...

en: I'm just kidding, the forest belongs to no one. Take all the bamboo that you need.
fr: Je rigole ! La forêt n'appartient à personne. Prends tous les bambous dont tu as besoin.

en: Is it well enough for the pandas' god?
fr: Est-ce assez bien pour le Grand Panda ?

en: I see you little bamboo!
Oh! This one looks really tasty! Thanks a lot!
fr: Ho ! Celui là à l'air vraiment appétissant ! Merci beaucoup !

en: Yummy!
I will bloat if you keep doing that!
fr: Je vais exploser si tu continues !

en: Thank you for your kind offering young panda, you shall receive my blessings. I promise to protect you from the humans now and fo the rest of your days!
fr: Merci pour cette offrande jeune panda, reçois ma bénédiction. Je te protégerais toute ta vie durant contre les humains.

en: What is the meaning of this! [i]“Made in China”?![/i] Be wary of my wrath as I shall curse you and all your lineage!
fr: Quoi ? [i]Made in China[/i] ? Méfies-toi de ma colère, je pourrais jetter ma malédiction sur toi et tous tes descendants !

en: It's the pandas' god! I'm so honored to see it. I must carefully choose the bamboo I'll offer him.
fr: C'est l'esprit du Grand Panda ! Je suis si honoré de le rencontrer. Je dois faire très attention à quel bambou je lui offre.

en: I don't think he will fit in my bag...
fr: Je ne pense pas qu'il rentrera dans mon sac...

en: How do you like your bamboos?
Tasty.
And local!
A can
An old newspaper
It's a box
It's too heavy!
It's already open
There was a newspaper inside it
fr: Il y a un journal dedans

en: A chainsaw
A strawberry ice cream cone
fr: Un cône de glace à la fraise

en: res://scenes/test/dog_splash_theme.ogg
It smells so good!
I like to eat bamboo sticks.
It don't think it will answer me...
fr: Je ne pense pas qu'il me répondra...

en: Hello young panda, today is time for your first offering to the almighty panda god! I have prepared a bamboo stick for you, pick it up and bring it back to me.
fr: Bonjour jeune Panda, aujourd'hui tu vas réaliser ta première offrande à l'Esprit du Grand Panda ! J'ai préparé un bambou, va le récupérer et reviens me voir.

en: Now searching for the bamboo
fr: En train de chercher le bambou

en: Please go get the bamboo stick and give it to me.
fr: Va prendre le bambou et donne-le moi s'il te plaît.

en: The master knows how to please the pandas' god. I have to listen to him.
fr: Le maître sait comment plaire au dieu des pandas. Je dois l'écouter.

en: He will surely not appreciate it.
Good! You're qualified for the job! Now go to the forest and get some more bamboo. Be sure to offer them to our almighty panda god, it will give him strength to protect our land.
fr: Bien ! Tu es qualifié pour le travail ! Maintenant va dans la forêt et ramasse plus de bambous. Offre-les bien à l'Esprit du Grand Panda, cela lui donnera de la force pour protéger notre terre.

en: Oh no, another perverted young panda... This bamboo is made by humans, little one, not by Mother Earth! Plastic taste. Not good... Now go and give me a real bamboo!
fr: Oh non, encore un jeune panda perverti... Ce bambou a été fabriqué par les humans, petit, pas par Mère Nature! Goût de plastique. Pas bon... Maintenant va et donne-moi un vrai bambou!

en: I should talk to the master first.
fr: Je devrais d'abord parler au maître.

en: I already chose a bamboo.
Weird texture for a bamboo...
fr: Drôle de texture pour un bambou...

en: This bamboo looks so shiny and slick.
fr: Ce bambou à l'air si brillant et si lisse.

en: Hello bamboo, where do you come from?
use fallback!
I can't do that
fr: Je ne peux pas faire ça

en: pick_up fallback!
That's not a good idea
fr: Ce n'est pas une bonne idée

en: Hello I'm the ghost of Villa Majorelle, welcome to the game! Boo!
fr: Bonjour, je suis le vieux panda, bienvenue dans ce jeu !

en: My name is Arturo, I am a journalist and detective… my specials? Ghosts and thieves…
I write every month in the spooky review, “The ghosts are in” but the story I am about to tell you is for a different kind of readers indeed – the kind who want to take part in history…

The family of Louis Majorelle moved in 1902 to a beautiful villa on the outskirt of Nancy. It was specially built for them in a middle of a vast garden. They occupied the house fully until 1912, but as Jane Majorelle died and as Jacques was touring Europe and going even further on to explore North Africa, Louis Majorelle didn’t have the knack to stay around the Villa anymore, too much souvenirs, he says… The house was occupied by different offices before being in the care of a museum curator who carefully coordinated its restoration for years on, until the grand reopening of the Villa Majorelle Nancy to the public in 2020.

I was invited to the event as many of my colleague journalists and rejoiced the wonderful restoration, with original furniture and decorative art pieces of the Majorelle family or very similar… It felt like the Majorelle family was still around... And I actually wasn’t far from the truth… As, quickly after the reopening, the Villa Majorelle closed again. No explanation was given… until one fine day, I receive this letter:

Dear Arturo,
One of my museum colleagues gave me your name, saying you are a kind of medium spirit or something as well as a journalist and detective… I am not too much in those airy fairy stories to be perfectly honest with you, but the most peculiar things happened in our Villa Majorelle in the last month of winter: objects were moving on their own, disappearing and reappearing… I am too much of a sceptic to believe in anything above my understanding, but as a matter of fact, I think that we may have ghosts in! Those ghosts can’t be dislodged; they are the Majorelle family, in their own home! Trapped in! But they do need to be pacified so we can reopen the Villa Majorelle to the visitors.
We need your help! Please help!
Yours truthfully,
The Curator

Hmm…! Interesting… Everyone thought the Majorelle family was gone but their souls are still errands in this special Art nouveau Villa… but why are they trapped? Why do they haunt the Villa? Sometimes souls stay around because a matter has to be settled…
This is a perfect case for me…

The curator welcomed me one evening, tight smile on her lips, not too comfortable with the situation at hands. I try to comfort her, but as I went in I could already feel something is the air… something moving really fast around me, jumping… She pushed me through the living room and suddenly said to me: Sir, I don’t want any trouble, so either you get the matter sorted quickly – let’s say an hour, or you stay in with the ghosts and this Villa, well forever!

And she turned her heels quickly, closed the door shut behind her with the keys, then I could hear her shouted  the main door closed too and the cricking of the garden gate closing behind her finally.
I was left here, locked in the villa, in its grand dining room, with little time in hand and with no clue whatsoever where to start… All alone, or so I thought…
First, I need to explore this room to collect some useful clues
